channel.title: I can't believe this
channel.description: I was playing runescape today and I was bored, so I decided to click on one of the ads. It took me to a site where I could download an "upgrade" that was a .exe file of 63 kb. I knew better than to download it, but after I closed the window NOD32 came up and detected a file in my temporary internet files. It was deleted, so I'm fine. But I can't believe that those faggots at JageX would support something that they obviously knew was a virus to send to thousands of unexpected people. That's pretty damn low.

item.title: I can't believe this

item.title: I can't believe this
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

They actually have little or no control over the ads. I forget how it all works, there is some info on the corporate site.

Remember the old ads about lingerie, and I think there was another one about genital warts or something.

Read full topic

item.title: I can't believe this
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Your all blaming Jagex. Why?

All Jagex do is host an image with a link, while the link could be 100% fine when Jagex check it, the next day the owner could use javascript to redirect it to another ad-site with a virus.

Hell, the ONLY ads I’ve seen on rs that aren’t suitable for younge people was back in rsc, you’ll see what I mean on the black book of rs cheating.

Read full topic

I was playing runescape today and I was bored, so I decided to click on one of the ads. It took me to a site where I could download an “upgrade” that was a .exe file of 63 kb. I knew better than to download it, but after I closed the window NOD32 came up and detected a file in my temporary internet files. It was deleted, so I’m fine.
